skill.name: memory-systems
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "implement agent memory", "persist state across sessions", "build knowledge graph", "track entities", or mentions memory architecture, temporal knowledge graphs, vector stores, entity memory, or cross-session persistence.

skill.author: ChakshuGautam

security_audit.summary: This skill contains documentation and pure Python data structure implementations for memory system architecture. No network calls, no filesystem access, no external command execution, no sensitive data access. The code runs entirely in-memory using standard libraries.

content.value_statement: Agents lose all knowledge when sessions end. This skill provides patterns for layered memory architectures that preserve entity knowledge, track relationships, and enable temporal queries across sessions.
actual_capabilities: Design layered memory architectures from context to permanent storage
Implement vector stores with metadata filtering and entity indexing
Build property graphs for entity relationship tracking
Create temporal knowledge graphs with validity periods
Implement memory consolidation to manage growing knowledge bases
Integrate memory retrieval with context systems
limitations: Does not provide database infrastructure or hosting
Does not include embedding model integration
Requires separate implementation of persistence layer
No built-in user authentication or access control

use_cases.title: Knowledge Base Building

use_cases.title: Shared Memory Across Agents

prompt_templates.title: Basic Persistence
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a memory system that can store facts about entities and retrieve them in future sessions.

prompt_templates.title: Entity Tracking
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an entity memory pattern that maintains identity, properties, and relationships for entities mentioned across multiple conversations.

prompt_templates.title: Temporal Queries
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a temporal knowledge graph that supports queries like what was the users address on January 15, 2024.

prompt_templates.title: Consolidation
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement memory consolidation that merges duplicate facts, updates validity periods, and removes outdated information.

output_examples.input: Implement a memory system for a customer service agent that remembers user preferences and previous issue resolutions.
output: Architecture: 3-layer memory system with session state, user profile memory, and resolution knowledge base
Layer 1: Short-term memory stores current conversation context and active task state
Layer 2: User memory tracks preferences, past issues, and resolution patterns
Layer 3: Knowledge base grows with successful resolutions indexed by problem type
Implementation uses vector store for semantic search and property graph for user-product relationships
Temporal validity tracks when preferences were last confirmed

best_practices: Match memory architecture complexity to actual query requirements
Implement progressive disclosure showing only relevant memories
Use temporal validity periods to prevent context clash from outdated information
anti_patterns: Storing everything in context without any memory architecture
Using simple vector stores for tasks requiring relationship reasoning
Never consolidating memories leading to unbounded growth

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Compatible with any LLM-based agent system.

faq.question: What are the memory size limits?
faq.answer: Memory limits depend on implementation. In-memory systems scale to available RAM. Database-backed systems scale with storage.

faq.question: How does this integrate with existing systems?
faq.answer: Provides patterns that work with any vector database, graph database, or storage layer. Implementation code is standalone.

faq.question: Is user data safe in persistent memory?
faq.answer: Memory data stays within your infrastructure. Implement access controls and encryption for sensitive information.

faq.question: Why are my memory queries returning outdated results?
faq.answer: Enable temporal filtering or run consolidation. Without validity periods, old facts remain in results.

faq.question: How does this compare to vector RAG?
faq.answer: Vector RAG provides semantic search. Knowledge graphs add relationship structure. Temporal graphs add time validity. Choose based on query needs.
